Services to Help the Poor and Needy

The following question stood in the name of Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng

1 Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports if there is a recommended approach by which help services for the poor and needy by the five CDCs and other helping hands can be better coordinated and communicated to minimise their falling through the social safety net.

2 Mrs Lina Chiam asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports with regard to the $61 million that was disbursed to 61,500 beneficiaries through the national ComCare schemes in 2010, how much did each beneficiary get each month.

Er Dr Lee Bee Wah : Question 1, Sir.

The Minister of State for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mdm Halimah Yacob) (for the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports) : Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I would like to take Question Nos 1 and 2 together.

Mr Speaker : Yes, please.

Page: 663

Mdm Halimah Yacob : Sir, the Community Care Endowment Fund (ComCare) provides assistance for low-income and needy Singaporeans. ComCare funding and programmes are delivered through our Community Development Councils (CDCs). ComCare beneficiaries are a diverse mix of needy Singaporeans who need different forms of assistance and for varying periods of time. Examples include elderly persons who are unable to work and need long-term assistance, families who require short-term help because the breadwinners have been retrenched from their jobs, families with members recovering from chronic illnesses and parents who require financial support so that their children can attend preschool. ComCare complements other support which the beneficiary may receive from his family as well as the help provided by various other help agencies in the community.

Mrs Lina Chiam asked about the amount of help each beneficiary receives each month. CDC officers will look at each individual's or family's circumstances, including factors such as household size and composition. Depending on the specific circumstances, the CDCs put together a package of assistance to address their needs. The help can be in form of cash assistance, free or subsidised medical care, vouchers for food, rental, utilities, service and conservancy charges, and preschool and student care subsidies. Because of this, it is not meaningful to provide an average figure on how much each beneficiary receives per month. However, we can give some typical examples.

For a family of four, where the male breadwinner with a homemaker wife and two preschool age children has recently lost his job, his family may be provided with $600 a month in cash allowances as well as vouchers for utilities and service and conservancy charges for three months. In addition, his children can receive up to $340 a month each in preschool subsidies, while the parents look for work. This is on top of the universal childcare subsidies which his children are already entitled to. For a couple where the husband has to stop working temporarily due to ill health and the wife has to be his primary caregiver, but has savings and some support from their children, he may receive $300 in cash a month while he recovers at home. They may also receive assistance for utilities and service and conservancy charges as well as rental assistance if they reside in a rental flat. For a single needy elderly without family support, he or she may receive $400 in cash allowances a month. In addition, there are other support such as free medical treatment at polyclinics and restructured hospitals, rental and utilities vouchers and community help. This additional support can amount to about $1,000 a month.

Ms Denise Phua asked how help services provided by the CDCs and other helping hands can be better coordinated and communicated to minimise their falling through the cracks. We agree on the importance of the CDCs to work with the various help services within their respective districts. Currently, this is done through the ComCare Local Networks. Today, nine ComCare Local Networks bring together various agencies comprising voluntary welfare organisations, citizens consultative committees, other social service agencies and even schools, hospitals and self-help groups. Through these networks, agencies come together to collectively identify and sort out systemic issues as well as work out processes to facilitate the referral of cases among the ComCare Local Network (CLN) partners and closing of referral loops. Working together, they are better placed to decide on the best approach to reach out to and assist the needy within their communities. Nonetheless, there is room for improvement.

More coordinated and integrated service delivery is an issue which the Ministry is looking at. We are working with our partners to identify ways in which we can adopt an even more client-centric, beneficiary-centric approach in the delivery of social assistance and services to the needy.

Ms Denise Phua Lay Peng (Moulmein-Kallang) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Minister of State for her comprehensive reply. I would like to ask the Minister of State if her Ministry would agree to conduct a survey of the different help agencies and find out what is happening now on the ground and how they are coordinated, so as to identify areas of best practices and improvement. I would also like to seek the Minister of State's response as to when the review would be done in order that an action plan can be developed as soon as possible to plug the gaps, so that those who fall through the cracks will be salvaged.

Mdm Halimah Yacob : Sir, I want to thank Ms Denise Phua for those questions. On the question of having a survey, I would like to inform Ms Phua that we do surveys on and off, although it may not be on a large scale. We constantly ensure that we test the waters and assess the environment in order to make sure that those who need help are getting the help that is available for them. Of course, we can always look into the possibility of conducting a much more comprehensive survey in order to see whether help is reaching the beneficiaries. In fact, we did a survey of 2,000 low-income households, those in the bottom 20%, and we received some feedback from them. They are the primary targets of our ComCare assistance schemes. We found that one out of 10 of these beneficiaries do feel that they need help but they have some difficulties getting it. What is also surprising to us is that about 60% of them, although they belong to the bottom 20%, indicated that they prefer to be self-sufficient and that they do not need assistance. And so, we do have some surveys on and off to assess the situation on the ground.

On Ms Phua's second question as to when we will complete the review, this is an ongoing process. We share with the Member her sentiments that we should try to do it as quickly as possible, and that is obviously something that we are looking into. Just to reinforce the point that our primary consideration is that those who need help will get the help. They must get the help. This is where we are also strengthening our CLN, by working with the CDCs, our primary agencies, our family service centres and other VWOs. In the longer term, we are looking at other possible structures as well like, developing the service hubs. We have in mind two models. One is more programme-centric and the other is more client-centric, depending on what are the most feasible options available.

Mrs Lina Chiam (Non-Constituency Member) : Sir, I would like to thank Mdm Halimah Yacob for the answers. I would like to ask two supplementary questions. First, would the Ministry set up a one-stop assistance centre where officers can work with community and social workers to provide details on all schemes, including those run by charitable and non-governmental organisations so as to achieve on a coordinated and targeted basis, the best way to address the needs of the poor and needy in getting the right help at the right time, like assistance in terms of housing, children's education, medical needs and financial counselling in regard to retrenchment in jobs and advice on dealing with creditors?

Secondly, to ensure that the needy who are poorly-educated and unaware of such schemes do not fall through cracks in our social safety system, will the Ministry set up a committee to brainstorm ideas for more publicity through the mass media on the financial help offered by the ComCare schemes?

Page: 665

Mdm Halimah Yacob : Sir, I want to thank Mrs Lina Chiam for those questions. I think the crux of the issue underlining both questions is how we ensure that the needy and those who need help are able to access the help that are available to them. That is the basis of her question for having a one-stop centre and also in having a committee in order to look at these issues. On the question of a one-stop centre, the problem with having just a one-stop centre is that it can become a bottleneck. And especially when we want to make sure that the touch points that we have are spread all over the island and not just within a one-stop centre. Instead of having a one-stop centre, what we have now is a situation where we work very closely with our partners. So, we have nine ComCare Local Networks under the CDCs and through those ComCare Local Networks, we bring together all the touch points needed throughout the island. So, there are the CDCs, the family service centres, and the VWOs dealing with different areas of needs of our beneficiaries and our needy persons. All of them are brought together under the ComCare Local Networks. The ComCare Local Networks act as a focal point where it also provides a platform for all the various agencies providing help to the needy to come together to discuss and share experiences and notes on how to extend assistance and help to the needy. Instead of a one-stop centre, what we have in mind, as I mentioned earlier, is to develop service hubs. Service hubs are structures where we either have it as programme-centric or client-centric located in one location, and where we bring all the service providers together. For instance, if we need to take care of the elderly, we need to bring all the providers together, whether it is the family service centre or the VWOs taking care of the elderly needs. They will then be co-located. As Members are aware, a structure like this takes a bit of time to develop but this is one of it.

The Member's second question is whether we can have a committee. We all know very extensively and comprehensively the issues, challenges and problems that we face. It is not necessary for us to set up another committee to look into this issue. What we need to do is to identify what are some of the gaps, which we are doing right now, and also to address those concerns and issues. I must say that looking at the structures that we have, it is for the moment able to reach out to the needy and the beneficiaries. There are areas where we need to do more outreach, particularly for those who are at the bottom 20%. One out of 10 in our survey says they do face some difficulties. This is where we will then work very closely with our grassroots organisations and VWOs to work out an outreach strategy for them.

Mr David Ong (Jurong) : Sir, I thank the Minister of State for her reply. We are grateful for the service hubs and the CLNs, but I think what is probably lacking is an integrated information or database of those who are in need of help. Sometimes, we may or may not know who had been helped. I would like to ask the Ministry if there are any plans for a more client-centric approach in integrating information from the various agencies and make the information more accessible to the CDCs and the grassroots, so that those who come to us for help can be helped quickly and holistically.

Mdm Halimah Yacob : I thank the Member for that question. We do actually have a database of those who need help and have come to seek help, not just from the Members of Parliament and the advisors, but also from the various VWOs. This database is accessible. Sometimes, the gaps are dependent on what information each individual advisor puts into the database. But the database is there. We are currently also looking at how to further enhance and improve the database.

Mr Speaker : Ms Irene Ng – last question.

Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines) : Sir, the Minister of State mentioned that there are needy residents who prefer to be self-reliant and refuse welfare help. Can I ask the Minister of State for an assessment of how big this group is from the group of needy residents that have been reached out to? Also, what is the MCYS' approach towards groups of residents who are publicly going out to seek help such as by selling tissue papers or appearing very hard-up in public but, when approached by MCYS, refuse public welfare?

Mdm Halimah Yacob : Sir, I just want to repeat the call that we have made repeatedly. If there are any such cases of needy residents or Singaporeans that any Member of Parliament comes across, do please refer them to us, and we will follow up or refer them to our five CDCs, so that they can also follow up with the relevant assistance and support. With regard to some Singaporeans whom we feel may need help, but they feel they can manage on their own, I think the real issue is this:That we should also respect people's desires and wishes.

As I was growing up, I belonged to the bottom 10% of the population. Very often, when I was in school, my teachers would tell me, "Why do you not go and ask your mother to go and get social welfare or social assistance?" But my mother would be terribly horrified with any suggestion that she should go and get social welfare or social assistance. Because when my father died when I was eight years old, my mother said that so long as she has two hands and two legs, we will all survive.

So, we need to respect the desires of people, even though they may be at the bottom 20%, when they say that they want to have ownership of their lives. They want to decide whether they want to seek help or not to seek help. We cannot say that just because you are at the bottom 20%, we must therefore extend our help to you regardless of whether you want it or not. I think that should not be the philosophy that we should adopt, but rather, we should adopt a philosophy where we provide them with the dignity, the support and the level and kind of assistance that they need.

Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) on Weekends

(Review)

3 Mr Liang Eng Hwa asked the Minister for Transport whether the Ministry would review the need (i) to impose ERP charges on weekends and (ii) to extend the ERP cordoning strategy to weekends.

The Minister of State for Transport (Mrs Josephine Teo) (for the Minister for Transport) : I thank Mr Liang for his question. Traffic congestion at any time leads to a sub-optimal use of our road network. It undermines our quality of life, the environment, and the overall efficiency of the economy. Congestion therefore needs to be kept in check. Where possible, traffic engineering methods, such as road widening, have been implemented to relieve congestion. However, where such solutions are not available or have been exhausted, Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) has been introduced.

Page: 667

We have generally applied ERP based on ensuring an optimal travel speed either on individual roads, such as expressways and major arterial roads, or to the city area using a cordon concept. The cordon concept, where all routes entering the same area are priced uniformly, is necessary because the roads leading into the city area are fairly good substitutes for one another. The lack of a cordon would only lead to traffic diverting into roads that are not priced or priced lower, resulting in greater localised congestion.

The reasons for introducing ERP on Saturdays for the Orchard and Bugis-Marina Centre cordons in 2005 and 2008 respectively still stand today. Since its implementation, ERP has improved traffic speeds within these cordons and maintained them within the acceptable range. ERP rate reviews are carried out quarterly, as well as for the June and December school holidays, to ensure that ERP rates remain relevant to the traffic situation.

While the core principles of ERP remain essential, we will continue to be flexible at the margins where there is room to fine-tune the system. For instance, we recently shortened the evening ERP operating hours for gantries along the northbound Central Expressway (CTE) before the Pan Island Expressway (PIE) and the southbound Singapore River Line, taking into consideration public feedback, traffic conditions and travel patterns. In response to feedback on weekend ERP and cordon charging, and also to take into account the changes in the road network in the vicinity of Marina Centre area, we will be moving the Nicoll Highway gantry in 2012 and adjust the Bugis-Marina Centre cordon, to enable motorists to access the East Coast Parkway (ECP) via the Nicoll Highway without having to pass through and pay ERP at the cordon. In doing so, motorists will have a greater choice in choosing their travel routes and times. Motorists who want a smoother drive can still do so by paying the ERP charges. We will continue to monitor the traffic situation and fine-tune the ERP scheme where necessary.

Mr Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah) : Sir, we are talking about Saturday's ERP. It is a non-working day, a day where the office CBD crowds are not rushing to get into their offices. Perhaps the impact to economy would be less severe. I would like to ask the Minister of State whether LTA can go a little easier on Saturdays in their road management and perhaps even do a trial and see if we were to switch off the ERP on Saturdays, what will be the difference in the behaviour of road users. Perhaps we may learn something new from there in how we can manage traffic. I hope the Minister of State would look into this – whether there is a necessity to have ERP on Saturdays, given it is a non-working day.

Mrs Josephine Teo : I thank Mr Liang for his supplementary question. Let me reassure the Member that the decision to implement Saturday ERP for these areas was not taken lightly. Average speeds had deteriorated to below 20 km/h before ERP was introduced. This has since improved and speeds are now kept within the optimal range between 20 km/h and 30 km/h. Even on Saturdays, there are economic activities like the retail trade in the Bugis-Marina Centre and Orchard areas. So, taking these factors into consideration, the ERP will continue to be implemented in these areas. Having said that, ERP implementation is not static and we will continue to fine-tune it from time to time.

Double-car Trains for Sengkang LRT System

4 Dr Janil Puthucheary asked the Minister for Transport whether LTA would work with SBS Transit to implement double-car trains on the Sengkang LRT system.

Page: 669

Mrs Josephine Teo (for the Minister for Transport) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the Member for his question. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and the operator SBS Transit (SBST) monitor the passenger loading situation on the Sengkang-Punggol LRT (SPLRT) system closely. In recent years, ridership on the SPLRT system has increased, with year-on-year growth of about 10% from 2008 to 2011. Passenger loading levels have consequently also risen, with crowding observed during the morning peak travel at the last station on the Sengkang East loop in the direction of Sengkang Town Centre, where most commuters alight to transfer to the North-East Line.

LTA is currently undertaking a comprehensive review of the long-term capacity needed for the SPLRT system. One key aspect of this study was to determine the technical feasibility of converting the current one-car system to a two-car system, to increase the system's capacity in the medium to longer term. LTA is currently in the process of finalising the study and aims to share the findings in a few months' time.

While the study is still ongoing, LTA is concurrently looking at other possible alternatives to mitigate the crowding situation.

In the meantime, SBS Transit has implemented additional capacity enhancement measures, such as the addition of one LRT train to the Sengkang East loop during the morning and evening peak this year, which has resulted in 23 additional daily trips. As a result, commuters have seen waiting times improve from four minutes to three minutes during the peak periods. SBS Transit has also deployed Customer Service Officers (CSOs) at the Sengkang East loop to encourage commuters to consider taking the LRT in the less crowded direction, so as to optimise the system's bi-directional capabilities. One additional train has also been added to Sengkang West, resulting in reduced waiting times.

I would like to assure the Member that LTA will continue to work with SBST to monitor the passenger loading situation on the SPLRT system, and enhance the capacity and service levels where possible.

Dr Janil Puthucheary (Pasir Ris-Punggol) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I have a number of supplementary questions for the Minister of State after her very comprehensive reply. Could we have, perhaps, some indication of the time frame for the report of the comprehensive review? The second question I have is – given that there are number of new developments that are five to 10 years behind Sengkang in terms of infrastructure development and maturity as a town – Punggol being as an example – are there lessons learnt from the experience with the LRT system in Sengkang that are going to change the way LTA and the Ministry deal with public transport infrastructure in relation to population growth and development in new towns such as Punggol? Specifically, with respect to the last-mile concept for public transport which often is a friction for people to change their behaviour when a family moves in to a new location and buys a new BTO flat. This is an opportunity for them to reconsider and change their lifestyle with respect to public transport, perhaps. And very often, it is that last mile which is the determining factor. So, have there been lessons learnt from the experience in Sengkang which we will use to change either our operational approach or policy approach? And last question, would the Ministry consider either a structure or incentive system for the private transport operators to make them more likely to service this last mile in a way that our residents are likely to use even if in the short term it loses money?

Some establish a poverty line to identify those who need help. For example, in the United States, the 2010 threshold for a family of four works out to be about US$1,860 (S$2,390) per month. Based on this threshold, the US' poverty rate is about 15.1%. On the other hand, other countries like Canada and New Zealand do not have an official poverty line. Canada, for instance, adopts an income threshold, determined using family expenditure data, in guiding its assessment of the populace's needs.

There is no hard and fast rule on how to determine needs. In Singapore, we take an approach of tailoring our social safety net to different groups, depending on their needs and circumstances. This approach is more flexible and no less effective than countries that choose to adopt a poverty line. Our help schemes typically cover the bottom 20th percentile of households, with the flexibility to go beyond if the family's circumstances merit special consideration. This approach allows us to provide more targeted and customised forms of assistance with real outcomes for families and individuals.

The idea of a viaduct above Lornie Road or Bukit Brown was also looked at. This was found unsuitable because the building process itself would have the same if not greater impact than a road on Bukit Brown Cemetery. Likewise for the option of a tunnel, conventional excavation would have to be employed due to the required width of the tunnel and this would have an adverse impact greater than a road option.
